text:
Well, you can also do each of them in just one line:
```julia> const / = + ; sum(l -> eval(Meta.parse(replace(l, '+' => '/'))), eachline("input.txt"))
16332191652452

julia> const ^ = + ; sum(l -> eval(Meta.parse(replace(l, '+' => '^'))), eachline("input.txt"))
351175492232654```

elements.text: Well, you can also do each of them in just one line:

julia> const / = + ; sum(l -> eval(Meta.parse(replace(l, '+' => '/'))), eachline("input.txt"))
16332191652452

julia> const ^ = + ; sum(l -> eval(Meta.parse(replace(l, '+' => '^'))), eachline("input.txt"))
351175492232654

text: Sure, with semicolons you can put multiple expressions on one line ;)

elements.text: Sure, with semicolons you can put multiple expressions on one line ;)

text: Only one semicolon per line.  Even without them, it would be 4 lines compared to 20, 1/5th, and I do think the code is much easier to understand.

elements.text: Only one semicolon per line.  Even without them, it would be 4 lines compared to 20, 1/5th, and I do think the code is much easier to understand.

text:
That solution by <@UP0P065ME> looks nice, but it doesn’t really need to replace both `+` and `*`, since you only need to change the relative precedence.
I was feeling rather piratical this morning, and didn’t feel like looking up two Unicode characters that I could use that would have precedence the same as `*` and higher than `*` , so I just used `/` and `^`

elements.text: looks nice, but it doesn’t really need to replace both

, since you only need to change the relative precedence.

text:
Ok, here it is, no nasty stuff, one line / two statements:
```const ↑ = ⊗ = + ; [sum(l -> eval(Meta.parse(replace(l, '+' => ch))), eachline("advent18.txt")) for ch in ('⊗','↑')]```

elements.text: Ok, here it is, no nasty stuff, one line / two statements:
const ↑ = ⊗ = + ; [sum(l -> eval(Meta.parse(replace(l, '+' => ch))), eachline("advent18.txt")) for ch in ('⊗','↑')]

text: Pretty fun, being able to leverage the collective brainpower of the creators of Julia as well as all of the contributors over the years, to be able to do stuff like this, incredibly easily.
